docs.lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights awarded a woman 25,000 euros, about $33,000, in damages after doctors refused to grant her permission to terminate her pregnancy despite serious risk to her eyesight.

headline.main: Court Fines Poland Over Abortion Case
headline.print_headline: Court Fines Poland Over Abortion Case

docs.lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights on Tuesday awarded a 36-year-old Polish woman 25,000 euros, about $33,000, in damages after doctors refused to grant her permission to terminate her pregnancy despite serious risk to her eyesight. After her delivery, her eyesight deteriorated considerably, and she has been declared significantly disabled.

headline.main: Court Fines Poland Over Abortion Case

docs.abstract: European Court of Human Rights awards Polish woman about $33,000 in damages because doctors refused to allow her to end pregnancy despite serious risk to her eyesight; her eyesight deteriorated after delivery and she is disabled (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appellate panel ruled that the Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees because its insurance did not cover contraception used by men either.

headline.main: Court Says Health Coverage May Bar Birth-Control Pills
headline.print_headline: Court Says Health Coverage May Bar Birth-Control Pills

docs.lead_paragraph: Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Anders Thomas Jensen In Danish, with English subtitles Not rated; 91 minutes The Danish writer and director Anders Thomas Jensen's 2005 feature, ''Adam's Apples'' -- about a neo-Nazi sentenced to community service at a rural church run by a sunshine-and-lollipops vicar -- is one of the latest examples of the post-''Pulp Fiction'' bloody comedy. It's also one of the weirdest, mixing glib humor with dead-serious spiritual inquiry.
docs.abstract: Matt Zoller Seitz reviews film Adam's Apple, directed by Anders Thomas Jensen; Mads Mikkelsen and Ulrich Thomsen star; photo (M)
